metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Jalgaon Electric Supply Co., Ltd.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated September 9, 1955, of Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 37/x of 1954 under s. 66(1) of Indian Income-tax Act.

Tribunal referred two questions: (1) Whether there was any excess dividend declared by the assessee Company? (2) Whether the assessee Company is liable to pay additional income-tax in respect of the excess dividend paid?
High Court answered first question in affirmative (excess dividend declared), second in negative (no liability).
For assessment year 1949-50: book profits Rs. 1,22,469; after adjustments, assessed income Rs. 3,423; dividend declared Rs. 46,024.
For assessment year 1950-51: book profits Rs. 76,886; after adjustments, assessed income Rs. 3,312; dividend declared Rs. 56,326.

Income-tax Officer applied Proviso to Para. B of Part 1 of Third Schedule of Finance Act, 1949 and First Schedule of Finance Act, 1950, assessed difference to additional income-tax at 5 annas in the rupee.
Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, then to Tribunal.
In Tribunal, difference of opinion: President held no liability; Accountant Member held liable; third Member agreed with President.
Tribunal majority reason: no profits in years preceding the previous year, so Paragraphs could not operate.
High Court held excess dividends paid but absence of profits from previous years rendered Finance Act unworkable.
No undistributed profits from preceding years.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was any excess dividend declared by the assessee Company?
Whether the assessee Company is liable to pay additional income-tax in respect of the excess dividend paid?

petitioner_arguments.text: Fiction can be given effect even if profits of preceding years do not exist; chargeability arises under terms of Paragraph even then.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Proviso to Para. B of Part 1 of First Schedule of Finance Act, 1950 (corresponding to 1949)

petitioner_arguments.text: Intention of Finance Act to levy additional income-tax on excess dividends is plain.
Explanation provides for determination of years out of profits of which excess dividend comes; to escape liability, company must prove excess dividend bore tax at 5 annas/rupee.
Unjust to allow escapement of tax where no profits of preceding years.

respondent_arguments.text: No profits in years preceding previous year, therefore Paragraphs could not operate on their terms.

court_reasoning.text: Fictions postulate undistributed profits of preceding years sufficient to cover excess dividend and not previously used; where no such profits, fiction fails and method of calculation cannot apply.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Excess dividends first to be connected with profits of preceding years, then tax borne on those profits calculated; no preceding profits, no liability.

court_reasoning.text: Cannot whittle down fiction or assume liability; modification of language not permissible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Income-tax law must bring taxpayer within its letter; if fails, no unjustness.

court_reasoning.text: Scheme examined in Civil Appeal No. 427 of 1957; additional IT payable on excess dividends allowing for tax already paid on preceding profits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court repelled Commissioner's arguments correctly.

holdings.text: High Court answers correct: yes to excess dividend, no to liability for additional income-tax.
Absence of undistributed profits from preceding years renders proviso unworkable; no additional income-tax payable.

precedents_cited.relevance: Scheme of Finance Act in relation to excess dividends examined; reasons for no modification of language given there.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference under s.66(1); no order under s.23A; definition of dividend.

statutes_cited.name: Finance Act, 1949
sections: Proviso to Para. B of Part 1 of Third Schedule
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for additional income-tax on excess dividends for 1949-50.

statutes_cited.name: Finance Act, 1950
sections: Proviso to Para. B of Part 1 of First Schedule
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for additional income-tax on excess dividends for 1950-51; manner of calculating tax borne by excess dividend.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upholds Bombay High Court judgment, agreeing with Tribunal majority that no additional income-tax is payable on excess dividends due to absence of undistributed profits from preceding years, rendering the proviso unworkable.
outcome.relief_granted: No additional income-tax liability for assessee.

key_quotes.text: "Where there are no profits of any preceding year or years, the fiction wholly fails and the method of calculation, equally so."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning why no liability despite excess dividends.

key_quotes.text: "The Income-tax law seeks to put in the net certain class of income, and can only successfully do so, if it frame a provision appropriate to that end. If the law fail and the tax-payer cannot be brought within its letter no question of unjustness as such, arises."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects equity arguments for modifying statutory language.
